Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Safety of General Anesthesia in Pediatric Adenotonsillectomy

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence

Participants.evidence: Participants included children under 15 years old undergoing adenotonsillectomy, with eligibility criteria focusing on obstructive sleep apnea and other comorbidities.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received a specific anesthetic protocol, while the control group received standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study aims to evaluate the safety of general anesthesia in adenotonsillectomy

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of perioperative respiratory events, measured over a 24-hour postoperative period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in respiratory events compared to the control group (mean difference = 5.2 events, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with mild severity.

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by [Funding source].
